  • Open

    Govt’s Israel decision ‘took Israeli govt by surprise’: Sharma
    Former Israel Ambassador Dave Sharma says it is “very rare” for an Ambassador to be summoned by a Foreign Minister. It comes as Australia’s Ambassador will be summoned to Israel to explain the federal government's decision to reverse its recognition of West Jerusalem as the nation's capital. “I think that tells you that this Labor decision took the Israeli government by surprise,” he told Sky News Australia. “The normal practice if you’re doing something like this is to let your close partners and friends know in advance that such a decision is coming.”
    Penny Wong’s Israel announcement a ‘curious and unstructured’ way to roll out ‘important’ policy
    The Israeli Prime Minister has criticised the Australian government for what he calls a hasty decision to no longer recognise West Jerusalem as Israel's capital. Former Israel Ambassador Dave Sharma says the announcement by Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong yesterday was “a pretty curious and unstructured way to roll out a policy of this importance”. “Normally, a decision of this magnitude and consequence you’d expect a formal announcement,” he told Sky News Australia. “What instead happened was that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade changed the language on their website.”
    Tulsi Gabbard officially endorses Trump-backed Kari Lake
    Tulsi Gabbard has officially endorsed Trump-backed candidate Kari Lake for governor of Arizona just one week after announcing she was leaving the Democratic Party because it was under the “complete control of an elitist cabal of warmongers”.
    ‘Too hard, too fast’: Liz Truss’ tax cuts caught people ‘off guard’
    Freshwater Strategy Director Dr Michael Turner says UK Prime Minister Liz Truss’ policy delivery was carried out “too hard, too fast”. He said Ms Truss’ tax cuts caught people “off guard” and there didn’t seem to be a “solid plan”. “The fallout came not necessarily because the public thought that tax cuts were bad per se, but because the key stakeholders in society … reacted very badly to it, they weren’t informed,” Dr Turner told Sky News Australia. “And actually being Prime Minister is as much about the communications as it is about the policy, and you need to bring people with you.”
    ‘Wouldn’t rule it out’: ‘Chatter’ surrounding Boris Johnson’s political return
    Freshwater Strategy Director Dr Michael Turner says he “wouldn’t rule out” former UK prime minister Boris Johnson’s return to run for Conservative Party leadership. “There is some chatter among Conservative Party circles to let Liz Truss continue for another year or so and bring back Boris Johnson for the election,” he told Sky News Australia. “He certainly is someone who can communicate well and we’ll see whether or not that comes true.”
    ‘Horror show’: Liz Truss’ fallout has been ‘unreal’
    UK Prime Minister Liz Truss’ fallout has been a “horror show” since she delivered her budget, says Freshwater Strategy Director Dr Michael Turner. “The fallout post this mini-budget, which wasn’t so mini, has been unreal and since then it has been in a downward spiral,” he told Sky News Australia. “The chancellor has lost his job in order to try and save the Prime Minister’s and now we see the Prime Minister desperately trying to save her own.”
    Internet roasts ‘crazy’ Nancy Pelosi’s ‘delusional’ Joe Biden claim
    US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has been excoriated online after claiming President Joe Biden's first two years in office have been better "than most presidents that you can name".
    Israel’s furious response to Aussie backflip
    Israel has slammed Australia’s “wretched” decision to reverse its recognition of West Jerusalem as the country’s capital, while Palestinian terror group Hamas described it as “a step in the right direction”.
    ‘Completely unnecessary’: Birmingham slams government’s decision on Israel’s capital
    Shadow Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Birmingham says Labor’s decision to reverse the former government’s recognition of West Jerusalem as Israel’s capital was “completely unnecessary”. “This is a completely unnecessary decision by the Albanese government, handled in the most shambolic of ways,” he told Sky News Australia. “If we look through what has occurred, at the last election, senior Labor figures, the Attorney-General as he is now and others, reassuring Australia’s Jewish community there was no difference between the parties in relation to their support for Israel and their position on these sorts of matters,” Mr Birmingham said. “Then we had leaks coming out of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade this week, suggesting that there was to be a change in relation to Australia’s recognition of West Jerusalem as the Israeli capital – these were then emphatically denied by Minister Wong’s office itself. “And yet then hours later, we have the Minister coming out and making an announcement there has been a change in position – she did so on a holy day in the Jewish calendar, showing complete disrespect for the Israeli and Jewish communities in particular.”
    Albanese should ‘apologise’ to Israel’s PM for failing to show ‘basic diplomatic courtesies’
    Shadow Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Birmingham has criticised the manner in which Labor announced its decision to reverse the former government’s recognition of West Jerusalem as Israel’s capital. Foreign Minister Penny Wong announced on Tuesday that Australia’s position has “always been and remains” in Tel Aviv. Mr Birmingham said Mr Albanese should have “got on the phone” to Israel’s Prime Minister Yair Lapid before the decision was made and “consulted on the decision and advised and informed before it was being publicly announced”. “The test now is whether he will get on the phone and apologise for the shambolic way in which it was handled,” Mr Birmingham told Sky News Australia. “He should be apologising for failing to at least show the basic diplomatic courtesies of engagement prior to announcement.”

    Bond star Daniel Craig receives same medal as 007
    James Bond actor Daniel Craig on Tuesday received the same honor held by his fictional character, as he is set to retire from the role. The 54-year-old British actor who played Bond for the fifth and final time in 2021 film "No Time To Die", was made a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George, a rare honor that author Ian Fleming bestowed on his fictional agent. Craig bowed his head and smirked as Princess Anne, wearing naval uniform, put the order on its ribbon around his neck during an investiture ceremony at Windsor Castle. The actor received the honor for his outstanding contribution to film and theatre. Craig was in the British capital for the European premiere of whodunnit drama "Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery", which closed the BFI London Film Festival on Sunday. "We've been expecting you", the royal family's official Twitter account captioned its photograph, quoting a line famously used by a Bond villain. James Bond was said to have received the honor in his obituary in "You Only Live Twice," Ian Fleming Publications tweeted. It was not the first time Craig reprised his Bond role with the royal family in on the joke.     Discussing "sensitive" war topics, Russian Duma halts live broadcasts
    (Reuters) - Russia's Duma has indefinitely stopped broadcasting live plenary sessions to protect information from "our enemy", a leading lawmaker said on Tuesday as parliament's lower house debated topics related to the war in Ukraine. "Those questions that require sensitive discussion in a narrow professional circle should not be the property of our enemy," Vladimir Vasilyev, head of the dominant United Russia faction, told the military news channel Zvezda TV. Russia uses the term "special military operation" to describe what Ukraine and its Western allies say is a war of imperial conquest. Moscow says the West is engaged in a proxy war against it by hitting its economy with sanctions and providing Ukraine with cash, weapons and intelligence. The move meant there was no live broadcast on the Duma website or social media of Tuesday's session, where deputies were due to consider a report from Deputy Prime Minister Marat Khusnullin on the process of moving civilians to Russia from the Russian-occupied Kherson region of Ukraine, where Ukrainian forces are waging a counter-offensive. They were also due to consider a draft law that would allow the Defence Ministry to mobilise people who have committed grave crimes into the armed forces - repealing an existing ban on calling up criminals. Another deputy, Andrei Svintsov, said the broadcast restriction was imposed because most issues under discussion at the moment related to the "special military operation". He said live public broadcasts would resume once it was over. "Deputies ask questions and get quite frank answers. We understand that there may be some sensitive information from government representatives, from deputies," Svintsov said. (Reported by Filipp Lebedev; Editing by Mark Trevelyan)  ( 39 min )

Schönbohm helped set up the Cyber Security Council Germany 10 years ago.     Two killed in plane crash at Ohio car dealership
    Officials confirmed that their plane crashed at a car dealership in Marietta, Ohio, Tuesday morning, killing two people. The plane crashed in the dealership parking lot just after 7 a.m., and the Ohio Highway Patrol said the dealership and some vehicles in the parking lot were damaged. Officials said no one else was injured. The 1974 Beechcraft King Air E90 took off from Columbus at 6:35 a.m. for Parkersburg, West Virginia. Marietta is a town of approximately 13,000 people in southeastern Ohio, located north of Parkersburg on the Ohio River. The dealership is located in the main business district of the town. Some Marietta residents said they were awakened by the crash and saw a cloud of smoke rising into the sky. The fire at the crash site has been extinguished by firefighters. The Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board have launched an investigation into the cause of the crash. The names of the pilots and passengers killed in the crash have not been released.     Andrea Mitchell doesn't ask Josh Shapiro about the crime
    Violent and Property Crimes in Pennsylvania have only increased over the past year. Since October 13, there have been 429 homicides in Philadelphia in 2022, only three fewer homicides than their number at this point in 2021. Nearly 20 percent of California’s unemployment insurance payments in the first six months of the pandemic went to fraudulent claims, the Labor Department’s watchdog said. “Criminal businesses are finding that UI fraud is a low-risk, high-reward crime,” the inspector general said. “They invest their fraudulent UI proceeds in other criminal activities, such as buying guns and drugs.” The office, contacted by The Washington Times, declined to elaborate on the crimes, but did point to the Justice Department indictment.     War in Ukraine: Russian occupation leaves Donbas town of Sviatohirsk deeply divided
    Once so picturesque it was nicknamed the "Switzerland of the Donbas", the eastern Ukrainian town of Sviatohirsk today lies in ruins. It was recaptured by Ukrainian troops in mid-September after being occupied by Russian forces for nearly 100 days. Some locals welcomed the arrival of Russian troops, while others still struggle to contain their anger at the former occupiers. Sviatohirsk has long been known for its mixed loyalties and strong cultural ties to Russia. FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris Trent, Mélina Huet and RaId Abu Zaideh report.  ( 23 min )

    Australian Financial Review Special Correspondent Misha Zelinsky has discussed Russia’s recent drone strikes on the regions of Kyiv, Dnipro and Sumy which killed at least eight people in total. The drones appear to be Iranian-made ‘kamikaze’ drones. “What you are seeing increasingly now, as Russia is losing the war on the battlefield, you’re seeing what I describe as temper tantrum-type attacks designed to terrorise ordinary Ukrainians and also make their lives more difficult as we head into winter,” Mr Zelinksy told Sky News Australia. “They want to try to freeze Ukraine (sic) in their homes -inability to have electricity on, inability to heat your home – you can imagine what that would be like in a Ukrainian winter.”
    Penny Wong takes dig at Scott Morrison in Israel announcement
    Foreign Minister Penny Wong has taken a dig at former prime minister Scott Morrison’s attempt to “play politics” as she reversed the former government’s recognition of West Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. She said Australia’s embassy has “always been and remains” in Tel Aviv and Australia remains committed to a two-state solution. “I would say that Mr Morrison’s decision to play politics … resulted in Australia shifting position,” Ms Wong said during a media conference. “I know that this has caused conflict and distress in certain parts of the Australian community and today the government seeks to resolve that.”

    Cash is no longer king as small businesses go digital
    [Sponsored Article]   Thanks to the rise of smartphones and mobile technology, consumers are increasing their use of digital payment acceptance methods such as credit cards, mobile payment apps, and other forms of contactless payment methods to pay for everything, from big-ticket items to groceries and bus fares. It is more important than ever for small businesses to ensure they are not falling behind on the cashless trend. Over the past two years, the pandemic has accelerated this transformation, with Hong Kong seeing its largest drop in cash usage. The switch was most noticeable between 2019 and 2020 during the initial wave of the pandemic, according to a study on consumer payment attitudes carried out by Visa, a world-leading payment network. As more and more consumers demand cashless operations, the demand for small and micro businesses (SMBs) to support digital payments has also increased. Many of these SMBs are eager to adopt digital payment methods, and many now understand the benefits to their business when providing this option for customers.  "Setting up a point-of-sale terminal seemed daunting at first when we considered accepting digital payments," says Koyi Chan, owner of flower shop Botanic Union. "But it turned out to be less of a hassle than expected."  "Allowing our customers to pay digitally has had a huge impact on our business, especially during the Christmas season when people shop for Christmas trees and flowers at our shop and on our website. With customers being able to make transactions with just a tap, they'll feel secure and more inclined to spend more money,” she says.  Like Botanic Union, two in five small businesses in Hong Kong agree that accepting digital and contactless payments is among the top investment areas needed to meet customer expectations, according to ‘The Visa Back to Business Study’.     Chinese government hackers are  targeting America's state political parties: FBI
    During the 2016 election season, Russian hackers went after the national Republican and Democratic Party servers. Now according to the FBI, China is setting its sights on state parties, which likely have lower resources available for tech security. The Washington Post revealed that government hackers are scanning domains looking for possible vulnerabilities. Thus far, none of the possible targets have been hacked or breached. “The FBI is being considerably more proactive,” a senior U.S. official told the Post. “It’s part of a larger move that the FBI isn’t waiting for the attack to occur. They’re increasingly trying to prevent.” The official explained that scanning a network is likely part of a “comprehensive broad campaign” against the targets. “This is what they do.” The FBI said that they visited at least a dozen Republican Party headquarters offices. Agents spoke to Democratic parties in several states, but apparently didn't visit them personally. "The DNC and state parties have been in contact with the FBI,” the official said. “There is no evidence that any systems have been compromised.” “The RNC remains secure and we have not been compromised,” Republican National Committee spokesperson Emma Vaughn said in a statement to the Post. “Cybersecurity remains a top priority for the entire Republican ecosystem, which is why we place a premium on ensuring our stakeholders have the necessary tools, resources and training on best practices so that our Party remains protected and vigilant.” ALSO IN THE NEWS: Marjorie Taylor Greene serves notice to Kevin McCarthy that he needs to hand her 'a lot of power' See the full report at the Washington Post.  ( 37 min )

    US says it is 'confident' Pakistan can secure nukes after Biden uproar
    The United States said Monday that it had confidence in Pakistan's ability to control its nuclear arsenal after President Joe Biden expressed alarm, leading Islamabad to summon the US ambassador. "The United States is confident of Pakistan's commitment and its ability to secure its nuclear assets," State Department spokesman Vedant Patel told reporters. "The US has always viewed a secure and prosperous Pakistan as critical to US interests and, more broadly, the US values our long-standing cooperation with Pakistan," he said. Biden made the off-the-cuff remarks on Pakistan's nuclear program Thursday while at a private Democratic Party fundraiser in California where he began to discuss challenges facing President Xi Jinping of China, a close ally of Pakistan. "And what I think is maybe one of the most dangerous nations in the world: Pakistan. Nuclear weapons without any cohesion," Biden said, according to a White House transcript. Pakistan -- proud to be the only declared nuclear power in the Islamic world -- summoned US Ambassador Donald Blome to lodge a protest. Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif tweeted that Pakistan was a "responsible nuclear state" and that it takes safety measures "with the utmost seriousness." US officials have long privately voiced alarm about nuclear safety if the political situation changes in Pakistan, whose military and intelligence apparatus has assisted Afghanistan's Taliban. Foreign Minister Bilawal Bhutto Zardari said that Biden's remarks should not hurt relations, noting that the president was not speaking at an official function. But Bhutto Zardari, who recently visited Washington, called for more interaction, with Biden showing little interest in personally engaging his Pakistani counterparts. Patel noted, however, that USAID chief Samantha Power and State Department Counselor Derek Chollet have both visited since devastating floods hit Pakistan. "This is a relationship we view as important and it's something that we're going to continue to remain deeply engaged in," he said.  ( 42 min )

    'Classic Putin play': Former Trump official says Russia is using Elon Musk's 'ego' against Ukraine
    Fiona Hill, a former Trump adviser who also served as a key witness against him during his first impeachment trial, says she believes Russian President Vladimir Putin has been using Tesla CEO Elon Musk to exert diplomatic pressure on Ukraine. In an interview with Politico, Hill said that Musk -- who floated a widely panned "peace plan" between Russia and Ukraine and who also recently demanded that the American government start footing the bill for Ukraine's continued access to the Starlink satellite network -- is essentially being used as a conduit for Putin as he tries to end the conflict in Ukraine favorably on Russian terms. "This is a classic Putin play," she said of Musk's recent attempts to interject himself as a "peacemaker" between Russia and Ukraine. "Elon Musk has enormous leverage as well as incredible prominence. Putin plays the egos of big men, gives them a sense that they can play a role. But in reality, they’re just direct transmitters of messages from Vladimir Putin." Hill also outlined the ways that Putin often uses Russian-friendly businesspeople to act as his intermediaries as a way to get around traditional communications channels. IN OTHER NEWS: Prosecutors unveil sexually explicit messages between Oath Keepers founder and his lawyer "He is basically short-circuiting the diplomatic process," she explained.     Biden has 'no plans' to meet Saudi crown prince at G20 summit: US official

Stormy US-Saudi relations have seen new strain over Riyadh's recent support for oil production cuts, with Biden warning of unspecified "consequences." The move last week by OPEC+ -- composed of the Riyadh-led OPEC cartel and an additional group of 10 exporters headed by Russia -- would reduce global output by up to two million barrels per day from November. It could send energy prices soaring amid an energy crisis triggered by the war in Ukraine, and as inflation-weary American voters prepare to cast ballots in midterm elections. The move was widely seen as a diplomatic slap in the face, since Biden traveled …  ( 41 min )
    Brazil's Bolsonaro, Lula in first head-to-head debate
    Far-right incumbent Jair Bolsonaro and leftist challenger Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva traded jabs and insults as they squared off Sunday in their first-ever head-to-head debate, two weeks from Brazil's presidential runoff election. Lula attacked Bolsonaro as the "king of fake news," drawing accusations of lying, corruption and a "disgraceful" record in return, as the rivals sparred in the first debate for their polarizing second-round showdown on October 30. Lula, the charismatic but tarnished ex-president (2003-2010) who is seeking a comeback at 76, was particularly fiery criticizing Bolsonaro over his handling of Covid-19, which has killed 687,000 people in Brazil, second only to the United States. Attacking Bolsonaro over his resistance to buying vaccines and touting of unproven medicatio…  ( 42 min )
    Hungry elephants, Cameroon farmers struggle to coexist
    Banana growers on the edge of a giant national park on Cameroon's Atlantic coast say they can take no more crop destruction from hungry elephants as the conflict between man and animal escalates. Near the southern border with Equatorial Guinea, eight villages have registered complaints with the Campo Ma'an national park, a vast area of virgin forest from where the animals emerge. An estimated 500 gorillas and more than 200 elephants -- both endangered species -- roam the reserve's 264,000 hectares (652,000 acres). A week after elephants flattened his banana plantation close by the park, Simplice Yomen, 47, is struggling to cope. "We are at the end of our tether," he sighs. The elephants eat the new growth inside the banana tree trunks after splitting them open. Manioc, maize, sweet potato …  ( 41 min )

While his challenger, former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, vows to expand it. That’s what he did when he ran the country in the 2000s, and in northeastern Brazil, voters feel their very livelihoods depend on his return.

    Italian restaurant Campagnola abandons old New York digs for a modern space
    In a bold restaurant move to the Upper East Side, Campagnola – an “Italian country restaurant” at 1382 First Ave. for nearly 40 years – has moved from its apartment building to the modern Impala condo tower two blocks north at 1456 First Ave., where its new owner will be Aby Rosen’s RFR Realty. It’s a great change of venue for Campagnola, which has long attracted celebrities, politicians and senior law enforcement officials entering through a rustic front room with a vaulted ceiling. The menu’s hearty southern and northern Italian dishes are suited to the “country” theme and “meant to be shared,” its website says. But the president of Meridian Retail Leasing, James Famularo, who negotiated the lease for Campagnola owner Curt Huegel said Huegel “relyed on a talented designer, Delphine Mauroit, owner of DMDesign & Architecture, to capture the soul and vibe of the original” – possibly including the original bar, furniture and artwork. The new space in a former yoga studio at the base of the tower will have 3,400 “perfect L-shaped” square feet on the ground, Famularo said, plus 2,000 square feet in the basement. The configuration allows the dining room to occupy the entire ground floor. He couldn’t discuss the terms due to a nondisclosure agreement. The move is expected to take place in about nine months. The owner was replaced by Brandon Singer of MONA leasing, a brokerage firm backed by RFR. Huegel’s company, Host Restaurants, owns several major locations in and out of town. Among them is the Sefton Bar/Lounge opposite the original Campagnola – a lease which Famularo also managed. Huegel was always known for restaurantsnot for the bars – but Famularo said he got the idea from Sefton when he noticed many Campagnola customers were looking for drinks nearby while waiting for their tables. Source Link  ( 24 min )

    US computer chip export rules having ‘dramatic effect’ on Chinese manufacturing
    Former DFAT Australia-China Council scholar Andrew Phelan says the US sanctions recently imposed on the export of high-end computer chips to China have had a “dramatic” and immediate effect on manufacturing in the country. The Biden administration recently announced a set of controls that restrict the export of advanced chips, chipmaking equipment and design software created with technology from the United States. “Every American engineering executive involved in the chip manufacturing, chip industry in China has resigned, effectively immediately,” Mr Phelan told Sky News Australia. “And ASML, the Dutch supplier of the capital equipment that is used in making high-end chips has ceased servicing its Chinese customers. “So … I think the Americans anticipated the third term, they were worried about China’s advances in chips, in artificial intelligence, in weaponizing these things, so they have stepped in, in what is the biggest I think US move against China in the last several years.”  ( 17 min )

    India Aims to Develop Crypto SOPs During G20 Presidency, Says Finance Minister
    India’s Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman has revealed India’s plans to develop Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for cryptocurrencies during its G20 Presidency, from December 1, 2022 to November 30, 2023. Sitharaman has already called for global collaboration to decide the future of crypto and has been cautious against mainstream crypto adoption citing financial stability risks. However, speaking to local Indian journalists on October 15, she confirmed, “This (crypto) will also be part of India’s business (agenda during the G20 presidency). The G20, or Group of Twenty, is a global forum for addressing major issues related to the global economy. According to Sitharaman, no country alone can effectively manage or regulate crypto, adding that: “But if it’s platforms, asset exchanges that have been created, buying and selling making profits and most importantly, these countries are able to understand the trade of money, are we able to establish for what purpose it is used? Sitharaman further pointed to the use of crypto assets in money laundering, detected by India’s law enforcement agency, the Enforcement Directorate. She added that G20 members have also acknowledged the same concerns while reiterating the need for all countries to participate when it comes to effectively regulating crypto assets. Related: Polygon Powers Indian Police Complaints Portal and Fights Corruption On October 7, the Reserve Bank of India released a list of proposed features and the reasoning behind its development. central bank digital currency (CBDC). The 51-page document summarizes the main motivations for issuing the digital rupee, including trust, security, liquidity, finality and settlement integrity. Some of the main motivations behind Indian digital currency are reducing operational costs and improving financial inclusion. Source Link  ( 24 min )
